comments:
This course examines limitations in psychosocial functioning of individuals and families that are due to psychiatric disorders. Content focuses on the biobehavioral basis of psychiatric disorders, as well as the psychosocial, developmental, and physiological needs of individuals and their families. Care of individuals having acute episodes and chronic problems are discussed.

Students for the most part enjoyed this course; however, some felt that the use of more “science” and less “common sense” would have been beneficial. There was a sense that while the materials were interesting, it would have helped if the knowledge was more relevant to clinical. Students suggest that the lecturers might bring in more “extraneous” material. Though, the knowledge provided by the course instructors was supplemented by a series of guest lecturers that students thought were great and one student remarked that, “many of the lecturers were the best I have ever experienced.”

Students remarked that Professor D’Antonio was “accessible for questions” and students “felt comfortable approaching her in class” and via e-mail with concerns. Professor D’Antonio shared experiences with the students which made it easier for them to learn how to handle difficult patients. However, sometimes students believed the power points were too dense or that the professor simply read off the slides. Other students mentioned that Professor D’Antonio’s strategy of asking students to discuss questions amongst themselves and then report to the class disrupted class flow. But students felt that, overall, Professor D’Antonio answered their questions over the course of the class period.

The class is only half a semester and students found that the workload was heavy. One student warned that “the readings at the beginning of the semester are a lot” of work. Students found the group assignments to be overwhelming and somewhat unnecessary. Many suggested that only one project be done instead of two as the students’ schedules are often overloaded from clinical, class and other courses’ classwork. Some students also felt the exams were not helpful in extending knowledge since the content was more intuitive and subjective. Other students commented that the exams were fair and covered good material. The class is designed for senior nursing majors and the pre-requisite courses are NURS 210, 220, 240, 270. The co-requisite course is NURS 322.
